column1: Total Sources Analyzed: 70+ peer-reviewed papers, patents, databases, and technical reports
The electrochemical synthesis of graphite from CO₂ and other carbon precursors in molten salt electrolytes has
emerged as a transformative approach to address both carbon emissions and critical material supply challenges.
This technology operates at temperatures as low as 126°C to 900°C (compared to traditional Acheson process
at >3000°C), offering potential energy savings of 80-95% while simultaneously capturing CO₂. Recent
breakthroughs (2023-2025) include novel electrolyte compositions, AI-driven catalyst discovery, and improved
Composition                                      Key Advantages          Main Products       Reference
Li₂CO₃-Na₂CO₃-K₂CO₃                              Low eutectic temp,      Amorphous to        [Multiple,
Li₂CO₃ + NaVO₃ (15                               Homogeneous catalytic   Graphitic carbon
Breakthrough Discovery (2024): Strontium carbonate electrolytes demonstrate comparable CNT purity to
lithium carbonate while reducing electrolyte costs from $23,000/ton (Li₂CO₃) to ~$500/ton (SrCO₃). This
addresses lithium scarcity concerns for battery applications.
• Single-step reduction: CO₃²⁻ + 4e⁻ → C + 3O²⁻ (thermodynamically favorable at <800°C)
• Oxide regeneration: CO₂(g) + O²⁻ → CO₃²⁻ (enables continuous operation)
Composition                        Key Features             Carbon Products            Applications
CaCl₂-NaCl-CaO                     Excellent CO₂ capture,                              LLNL patent US
LLNL Innovation (2020): CaCl₂-CaCO₃-CaO system enables graphite production at 825°C with:
• Energy consumption: 50-70% less than Acheson process
• Li₂CO₃ + 1.0M Li₂O: Improved nucleation for straight CNTs
• CaTiO₃ additives (0.8 wt%): Passivation of carbon anodes, preventing corrosion
• Li-K-Na carbonates at 500°C: Scroll-like tubular structures with Cu-containing anodes
• Surface area: 400-520 m²/g, pore volume: 0.8-1.3 cm³/g
• LiOH-NaOH with carbonates: Enhanced CO₂ conversion at 550-600°C

Innovation (2023): Nickel foam cathodes enable controlled directional carbon precipitation, creating graphite
• Fast-charging capability: 80% capacity in 6 minutes (vs. 40% for commercial)
Inert oxides       RuO₂-TiO₂, RuO₂-IrO₂          High stability, O₂ selectivity        Expensive ($2000-5000/kg Ru)
Carbon-based       Graphite, glassy carbon       Low cost, available                   Consumable (oxidizes to CO₂)
Perovskites        SrTiO₃, CaTiO₃                Moderate cost, stable                 Lower conductivity
Metal alloys       Ni-Cu, Fe-Ni-Cr               Catalytic for specific products       Corrosion issues
Cost-Performance Trade-off: Transition from RuO₂ to perovskite/carbon anodes critical for
commercialization. CaTiO₃ passivation layers (Trans. Nonferrous Met. Soc. China 2024) show promise.
• Transition metals (Ni, Fe, Co, Cu): 0.5-5 wt% → CNT nucleation

Key Insight: Transfer learning from Redlich-Kister models to DNNs enables accurate predictions for molten
salt systems with sparse experimental data.
• Framework: Database → ML models → AIMD simulations → DFT calculations → Experimental
• Application: Multicomponent molten catalysts for CH₄ pyrolysis (analogous to CO₂ conversion)
• Impact: 36.3% efficiency improvement in molten metal catalysts

Breakthrough (2024-2025): Machine learning force fields (MLFFs) enable 1000x speedup vs. DFT while
maintaining ab initio accuracy for molten salt simulations.

• Scale-up data (most studies at <1 kg scale)

• C2CNT (Founded 2017): Piloted 11,000 cm² electrode at Shepard Natural Gas Plant (Calgary) producing
• Estimated Production Cost: $791/ton CNT (SrCO₃ electrolyte) vs. $2005/ton Al production
• Critical Mineral Status (US DOE 2023): Strategic importance for battery supply chain
• Lab-scale (1-10 kg): TRL 4-5 (demonstrated in relevant environment)

1. Reduce electrolyte cost: Li₂CO₃ → SrCO₃ (✓ achieved 2024)
• Standardized reporting of electrolyte composition, T, current density, carbon product characterization
• Graphitization degree as f(T, V, t, cathode material, additives)
• Interpretable models linking atomic structure → conductivity → carbon product
• Graph neural networks for reaction pathway prediction

2. In-situ characterization (XRD, Raman, DEMS) during electrolysis
3. Techno-economic analysis (TEA) for 1-10 ton/day pilot plants
1. AIMD simulations of CO₂ dissolution and reduction mechanisms in mixed salts
2. DFT calculation of graphitization barriers on different cathode surfaces
3. ML model training on combined experimental-computational datasets
2. Integrate with MatML, Materials Project schemas
1. Demonstrate 100 kg/day pilot with >85% carbon efficiency and <1.0 kWh/kg
2. Qualify battery-grade graphite from CO₂ (ICP-MS purity, electrochemical testing)
3. Integrate with industrial CO₂ sources (cement, steel, power generation)
1. Active learning framework for real-time process optimization
2. Digital twin of molten salt reactor for predictive maintenance
3. Generative models for novel electrolyte discovery (analogous to MOF, battery electrolytes)
1. Modular 1-10 ton/day reactors with continuous operation
2. Automated carbon harvesting and salt recirculation
3. Waste heat recovery for thermal management
• Target: 1000+ ton/day facilities co-located with CO₂ emitters
• Product Mix: 60% battery-grade graphite, 30% CNTs, 10% graphene
• Revenue Model: Carbon product sales + CO₂ credits + avoided graphite imports
• Environmental Impact: 2-5 Mt CO₂/year captured per facility
1. Room-temperature electrochemical graphitization in ionic liquids
2. Plasma-assisted molten salt synthesis for <400°C operation
3. Direct air capture → graphite in single integrated process
4. Quantum computing for molten salt reaction dynamics
The field of molten salt electrochemical graphite synthesis has advanced significantly from 2020-2025, with
1. Electrolyte chemistry: SrCO₃ as Li₂CO₃ alternative addresses cost and supply chain
2. Process optimization: Pulse electrolysis, nickel foam cathodes enable battery-grade graphite
3. Mechanistic understanding: AIMD/DFT reveal graphitization pathways
4. AI integration: ML models predict properties with near-experimental accuracy
5. Scale demonstration: C2CNT pilot produces kg-scale CNTs from industrial CO₂
• Data: Establish comprehensive, AI-ready molten salt database
• Materials: Develop cost-effective inert anodes (perovskites, ceramics)
• Process: Scale from kg/day to ton/day with continuous operation
• Integration: Couple with renewable energy, industrial CO₂ sources
Transformative Potential: If technical and economic barriers are overcome, this technology could:
• Capture 10-50 Mt CO₂/year by 2035 (if widely deployed)
• Secure battery supply chains for EV transition
• Create $10-50 billion/year market for CO₂-derived graphite
The convergence of electrochemistry, molten salt science, and AI-driven discovery positions this field for
breakthrough commercialization within the next 5-10 years.
